= a way of learning mandarin chinese =

This blog's purpose is to commit to and keep a trace of my progression in the journey to learn how to speak mandarin chinese, as well as how to read and write simplified chinese.

All ideas here are inspired from other people's methods and their returns on experience, making a mixture of them.

The framework used for writing and maintaining this 'blog' is [[vimwiki||https://vimwiki.github.io/]], 
Which is a Vim plugin that helps writing markdown-style syntax, and ships with a "mardkown to html" engine. It is simple. You should give it try.

VimWiki Developers: Feel free to *add* to this wiki for additional test features.

The first method to apply, just like for financial asset management (let's consider your personnal knowledge in a particular domain an asset) is as simple as diversification. You don't need to change your learning method every week, but adding variation in the way you learn, at least sometimes, can keep you up motivated and, can be used to verify your progress or even verify that you are not using the wrong method.

There are methods you can use as a beginner, others that must be used on the long term.
Spaced repetition, in my opinion, is a very good method, but it depends on the way it is applied.
Using a numeric spaced repetition tool (a tool such as anki) is, in my opinion, a false friend. todo.............args in a separate wiki page
